isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - FULLER 10 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS - ASSEMBLE - MAINSHAFT

note.para: Any spline can be used for the key location.
While assembling the components, refer to the cross section in Figure 127. When the mainshaft and gears are assembled correctly, the assembly will have the same shape as the cross section.

step1.para: With mainshaft pilot-end (small end) down, secure the mainshaft in a vise with brass jaw protectors ( Figure 128).
Identify and set aside the reverse gear. The reverse gear has three notches on the inside diameter that face the rear of the main case.
Slide a splined washer over the mainshaft into the lowest groove, and rotate the washer to offset the splines and hold the washer in place.

note.para: A spare piece of 12 inch long 5/32 inch air line can be used as a temporary key to assist in assembly. From the bottom, feed the air line up the keyway through the splined washers and gears to hold the components in place. After the mainshaft is assembled, the key can be inserted from the top as the air line is withdrawn ( Figure 128).
Any spline can be used for the keyway.
Six of the washers are the same size. Unlike previous Eaton Fuller transmissions, this transmission does not require gear endplays to be set.

step1.para: Position the smallest gear on the mainshaft with clutching teeth down.
Install a splined washer in the second groove against the gear. Rotate the washer to capture it in its groove.
With clutching teeth up, install the next smallest gear, making sure it rests against the splined washer below it.
Install a splined washer in the third groove. Rotate the washer to capture it in its groove.
With the missing internal splines aligned with the keyway, install the middle position sliding clutch (28 teeth).
Position a splined washer in the next available groove.
Position the next smallest gear on the mainshaft with clutching teeth down.
Position a splined washer against the gear. Rotate the washer to capture it in its groove.
Install the next smallest gear on shaft against 2nd speed gear with the clutching teeth up.
Position a washer against the gear. Rotate the washer to capture it in its groove.
With the missing internal splines aligned with the keyway, install the rear sliding clutch (28 teeth).
Position the reverse gear on the mainshaft and over the rear sliding clutch with clutching teeth down.
Position the reverse gear splined washer (large diameter washer) in the remaining groove.

Check the shape of the mainshaft against the cross section in Figure 127. If the mainshaft is assembled correctly, the shapes will be identical. If the shapes are different, disassemble the mainshaft and assemble it again.
Install the key from the rear of the mainshaft.
Remove the mainshaft from the vise, being careful that the key does not slide back out.
Lay the mainshaft on its side, and from the front, install the front sliding clutch (26 teeth). Make sure the missing spline lines up over the keyway.
